translated: Points of Controversy
The Great Fifty
The sixteenth section
The discussion of giving attention to what is attained
“Does one give attention to what is attained?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: tena cittena tam cittam pajānāti iti
translated: “Does one understand that mind with that mind?”
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: tena cittena tam cittam pajānāti iti
translated: “Does one understand that mind with that mind?”
“Yes.”

analyzed: tena cittena tam cittam cittam iti pajānāti iti
translated: “Does one understand that mind as ‘mind’ with that mind?”
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: tena cittena tam cittam cittam iti pajānāti iti
translated: “Does one understand that mind as ‘mind’ with that mind?”
“Yes.”
“Is that mind the object of that mind?”
“That can’t be said.”
“Is that mind the object of that mind?”
“Yes.”

original: Tena phassena taṁ phassaṁ phusati, tāya vedanāya …pe…
analyzed: tena phassena tam phassam phusati tāya vedanāya pe
translated: “Does one touch that contact with that contact, does one feel that feeling …🔽does one perceive that perception …🔽does one form that intention …

analyzed: tāya saññāya  tāya cetanāya  tena cittena
translated: does one cognize that consciousness …🔽does one think that thought …

analyzed: tena vitakkena  tena vicārena  tāya pītiyā
translated: does one ponder that pondering …🔽does one enjoy that rapture …
does one have that mindfulness …

analyzed: tāya paññāya tam paññam pajānāti iti
translated: does one understand that understanding with that understanding?”
“That can’t be said.”

analyzed: atītam atītanti manasikarontaḥ anāgatam anāgatanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the past as past, does he give attention to the future as future?
… He does not give attention to the future as future.

analyzed: atītam atītanti manasikarontaḥ anāgatam anāgatanti manasi karoti iti  āmantā
translated: When he gives attention to the future as future, does he give attention to the past as past?
… He does not give attention to the past as past.
When he gives attention to the past as past, does he give attention to the present as present?
… He does not give attention to the present as present.

analyzed: atītam atītam iti manasikaronto paccuppannam paccuppannam iti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the future as future, does he give attention to the present as present?
… He does not give attention to the present as present.

analyzed: atītam atītam iti manasikaronto paccuppannam paccuppannam iti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the past as past, does he give attention to the future as future and to the present as present?
… He does not give attention to the future as future and to the present as present.
When he gives attention to the future as future, does he give attention to the past as past and to the present as present?
… He does not give attention to the past as past and to the present as present.

original: Atītaṁ “atītan”ti manasikaronto, anāgataṁ “anāgatan”ti manasi karoti, paccuppannaṁ “paccuppannan”ti manasi karotīti?
analyzed: atītam atītam iti manasikarontaḥ anāgatam anāgatam iti manasi karoti paccuppannam paccuppannam iti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the past as past, does he give attention to the future as future?
… He does not give attention to the future as future.

original: atītaṁ “atītan”ti manasikaronto, anāgataṁ “anāgatan”ti manasi karoti, paccuppannaṁ “paccuppannan”ti manasi karotīti?
analyzed: atītam atītam iti manasikarontaḥ anāgatam anāgatam iti manasi karoti paccuppannam paccuppannam iti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he brings the past to mind as ‘past’, does he bring the future to mind as ‘future’ and the present to mind as ‘present’?
“Yes.”
… of three kinds of contact …
… of three kinds of consciousness come together?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: anāgatam anāgatanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he brings the future to mind as ‘future’, does he bring the past to mind as ‘past’?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: anāgatam anāgatanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he brings the future to mind as ‘future’, does he bring the present to mind as ‘present’?
“Yes.”
… of two kinds of contact …
… of two kinds of consciousness come together?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: anāgatam anāgatanti manasikaronto paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he brings the future to mind as ‘future’, does he bring the present to mind as ‘present’?
“Is it so that the Blessed One has not declared the four noble truths?” …

analyzed: anāgatam anāgatanti manasikaronto paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he brings the future to mind as ‘future’, does he bring the past to mind as ‘past’?
“Yes.”
… of two kinds of contact …
Is there a meeting together of two kinds of consciousness?
You say “No.” …

original: Anāgataṁ “anāgatan”ti manasikaronto, atītaṁ “atītan”ti manasi karoti, paccuppannaṁ “paccuppannan”ti manasi karotīti?
analyzed: anāgatam anāgatanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the future as future, does he give attention to the past as past and to the present as present?
You say “No.” …

original: anāgataṁ “anāgatan”ti manasikaronto, atītaṁ “atītan”ti manasi karoti, paccuppannaṁ “paccuppannan”ti manasi karotīti?
analyzed: anāgatam anāgatanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the future as future, does he give attention to the past as past and to the present as present?
“Yes.”🔽… Is there a meeting together of three kinds of contact …
… of three kinds of consciousness?
You say “No.” …

analyzed: paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the present as present, does he give attention to the past as past?
You say “No.” …

analyzed: paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the present as present, does he give attention to the past as past?
“Yes.”🔽… Is there a meeting together of two kinds of contact …
… of two kinds of consciousness?
You say “No.” …

analyzed: paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasikarontaḥ anāgatam anāgatanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the present thus ‘present,’ does he give attention to the future thus ‘future’?
… It is not so, Master Gotama.

analyzed: paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasikarontaḥ anāgatam anāgatanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the present thus ‘present,’ does he give attention to the future thus ‘future’?
… Yes, Master Gotama.🔽… Is there conascence of two kinds of contact …
… of two kinds of consciousness?
… It is not so, Master Gotama.

original: Paccuppannaṁ “paccuppannan”ti manasikaronto, atītaṁ “atītan”ti manasi karoti, anāgataṁ “anāgatan”ti manasi karotīti?
analyzed: paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti anāgatam anāgatanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the present thus ‘present,’ does he give attention to the past thus ‘past’ and to the future thus ‘future’?
… It is not so, Master Gotama.

original: paccuppannaṁ “paccuppannan”ti manasikaronto, atītaṁ “atītan”ti manasi karoti, anāgataṁ “anāgatan”ti manasi karotīti?
analyzed: paccuppannam paccuppannanti manasikarontaḥ atītam atītanti manasi karoti anāgatam anāgatanti manasi karoti iti
translated: When he gives attention to the present thus ‘present,’ does he give attention to the past thus ‘past’ and to the future thus ‘future’?
… Yes, Master Gotama.🔽… Is there conascence of three kinds of contact …
… of three kinds of consciousness?
… It is not so, Master Gotama.
It is not to be said that
he gives attention to it having attained it.
… Yes, Master Gotama.

analyzed: nanu vuttam bhagavatā  sabbe saṅkhārāḥ aniccā ati
translated: Has it not been said by the Blessed One:🔽“When one sees with understanding
That all formations are impermanent,
Then one turns away from suffering,
This is the path to purification.🔽When one sees with understanding

analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā ti  yadā paññāya passati
translated: That all formations are suffering,
Then one turns away from suffering,
This is the path to purification.🔽When one sees with understanding

analyzed: sabbe dhammā anattā ati  yadā paññāya passati
translated: That all things are not self,
Then one turns away from suffering,
This is the path to purification.”
“Is there a sutta with this meaning?”
“There is.”

analyzed: tena hi adhigayha manasi karoti iti
translated: “Then you must have understood it well.”
The Discussion of Understanding and Recollection is finished.
